awd_titl_txt: FMitF: Collaborative Research: Track I: Embedding Constraint Reasoning in Machine Learning for Better Prediction and Decision-making
awd_abstract_narration:
The emergence of large-scale data-driven machine learning and optimization methods has led to successful applications in areas as diverse as finance, marketing, retail, and health care.  Yet, many application domains remain out of reach for these methods, when applied in isolation.  In the area of medical robotics, for example, it is crucial to develop systems that can recognize, guide, support, or correct surgical procedures. This is particularly important for next-generation trauma care systems that allow life-saving surgery to be performed remotely in the presence of unreliable bandwidth communications. For such systems, machine learning models have been developed that can recognize certain patterns, but they are unable to perform under complex physical or operational constraints. Using constraint-based optimization methods, on the other hand, would allow the generation of feasible surgical plans; but currently, there is no mechanism to represent and evaluate such knowledge under complex environments. To leverage the required capabilities for real-life applications, this project develops an integrated method that Embeds Constraint Reasoning in Machine Learning (ECOR-ML). The researchers intend to demonstrate the effectiveness of ECOR-ML in the context of medical robotics. Prior research indicates that the integration of constraint reasoning and machine learning is essential for the development of safe and efficient technologies in this domain. The project aims to advance both machine learning and constraint reasoning technology, and will promote the cross-fertilization of formal and applied research in the areas of machine learning, constraint learning, and robotics.

The approach in this project provides a scalable method for machine learning over structured domains. The core idea is to augment machine learning algorithms with a constraint reasoning module that represents physical and operational requirements. Specifically, this research proposes to embed decision diagrams, a popular constraint reasoning tool, as a fully-differentiable layer in deep neural networks.  By enforcing the constraints, the output of generative models can now provide assurances of safety, correctness, and/or fairness. Moreover, ECOR-ML possesses a smaller modeling space than traditional machine learning approaches, allowing machine learning algorithms to learn faster and generalize better.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this research is to embed constraint reasoning in machine learning. As a result, the outputs of the machine learning models are guaranteed to satisfy key operational constraints, providing assurances of safety, correctness, and fairness. The need for the integration of reasoning and learning are prevalent. Many real-world applications involve extensive learning from large datasets and making predictions subject to complex constraints involving many thousands of decision variables. One such application can be found in the domain of medical robotics.  Recent developments have significantly enhanced the robots' ability to recognize, guide, support, and/or correct surgical procedures, based on machine learning methods that learn the movement of robotic arms from the data.  However, these systems are unable to incorporate physical and operational constraints that are required for a safe and correct practical deployment.  This is particularly important for next-generation trauma care systems, which would enable life-saving surgeries to be performed (semi-)autonomously in the presence of unreliable communications.

 

An important research outcome of this research is the COnstraint Reasoning Embedded Structured Prediction (CORE), a scalable constraint reasoning and machine learning integrated approach for structured prediction subject to combinatorial constraints.  The main idea is to augment structured predictive models with a constraint reasoning module that represents physical and operational requirements. Specifically, CORE embeds decision diagrams, a popular constraint reasoning tool, as a fully-differentiable module into recursive neural networks. To ensure constraint satisfaction, CORE filters out variable assignments predicted by the neural network that lead to constraint violations. With this integration, CORE provided structured prediction models with constraint satisfaction assurances. Moreover, due to constraint embedding, CORE has a smaller modeling space than other structured prediction approaches. This allows it to converge to good models faster, and the learned models generalize to unseen situations better.

 

CORE Enables Structured Prediction in Natural Language Processing and Data-driven Operational Research with Constraint Satisfaction: the PIs and students applied CORE on vehicle dispatching service planning in data-driven operational research, and if-then program synthesis, text-to-SQL generation in natural language processing. In all three applications, the structures generated by CORE 100% satisfy constraints when it is compiled from exact decision diagrams. Previous state-of-the-art approaches based on sequence-to-sequence neural networks rarely generate any structures satisfying constraints. In addition, CORE boosts predicting accuracy because of the reduced modeling space via constraint satisfaction.

 

CORE Produces Designs Satisfying User Specifications: the PIs and students also embed CORE as a spatial reasoning module in the SPatial Reasoning INtegrated Generator (SPRING) for design generation. Design generation requires tight integration of neural and symbolic reasoning, as good design must meet explicit user needs and honor implicit rules for aesthetics, utility, and convenience. Current automated design tools driven by neural networks produce appealing designs, but cannot satisfy user specifications. In SPRING, the spatial reasoning module driven by CORE decides the locations of objects to be generated in the form of bounding boxes. Embedding symbolic reasoning into neural generation guarantees that the output of SPRING satisfies user requirements. Furthermore, SPRING offers interpretability, allowing users to visualize and diagnose the generation process. SPRING is also adept at managing novel user specifications not encountered during its training, thanks to its proficiency in zero-shot constraint transfer.

 

Integrating Reasoning for Learning with Optimality Guarantees: Guarantees are crucial for many real-world problems. For example, can a road network design guarantee multiple safe evacuation routes when a natural disaster hits? Is a learned model the best fit to the training data? Answering these questions requires mixed symbolic and statistical inference with provable guarantees. On foundational language development, the PIs and students defined Satisfiability Modulo Counting (SMC) to unify these two types of inference. On foundational solver creation, they designed XOR-SMC, which attains a double-sided, constant approximation guarantee to solve the highly intractable SMC. Previous solvers offer arbitrarily loose, one-sided, or no guarantees. On domain-specific solver creation, XOR-SMC is optimized for core problems in diverse domains of AI and significantly advanced the state-of-the-art. Notable examples include new algorithms that converge in linear speed towards the true Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE) for Markov Random Fields (MRFs), optimal policies in stochastic optimization, true reward functions in maximum entropy inverse reinforcement learning, and Stackelberg equilibria of quantal response leader-follower games. Prior works for all these problems have no optimality guarantees. On interdisciplinary impact, a leader-follower game solver driven by XOR-SMC led to 19% shift of public effort towards areas of high scientific value in a citizen science game.

 

This award also supported forming the bridges between formal method and AI researchers, and between computer scientists and domain scientists. The core research outcomes have been applied to drive the progress in game theory, natural language processing, operational research, robotics, and AI-driven scientific discovery. Two new courses have been developed and taught to support such bridges.
